badly-done drag/cultural "costumes" bother me not just because of the bigotry, but because they seem to be poking fun at the thing they are not.

what if purim is not just about dressing up like what we aren't? what if it's dressing as what we COULD BE, but aren't (but might be?)

every year on yom kippur i remind myself over and over that yom kippur is a day like purim, a festival of outrageous joy.

today, two years into the Plague Times, i'm thinking of it the other way around. purim is holy because of its unique potential to make the impossible real.

i used to average a solid 4 tries on the wordle.

the longer i do it, the more often i end up with either 3s or 6s. either it's a good day and i get the pattern right away, or i am too cocky and waste a bunch of tries. no middle ground.

when the torah says shabbos is a delight, she is not trying to girlboss you into a hyper-restrictive lifestyle and then gaslight you for not enjoying it.

instead, the torah is reminding us that if our shabbat practice is not a delight, then something about it is NOT WORKING.

everyone is different and these same activities might be healing and regenerative for people who can approach them without the mental health baggage.

AND we need to recognize that people can be technically keeping shabbat but in a way that is harmful to their wellbeing.

a lot of the typical beginning-to-observe-shabbat advice--read a whole book, nap for hours, make tons of plans--are my actual go-to disassociation strategies. any shabbat practice that feels like "trying to make the time pass without noticing" is TOXIC for my mental health.

aspects of shabbat practice to lean into on weeks when it feels hard:
* really paying attention to the sunset/sunlight in general.
* nesting, loving hard on your home space and people/pets/comfort objects in it.
* sensory pleasures. wearing a silky robe, your comfiest socks.

this year i am committed to listening to indigenous wisdom, to work on repairing my own relationship with the land and my creator. to offer my labor not only to the continuation of capitalist-colonial cycles, but also to the earth and to my community. /5

but even if the colonial mindset shifts to broaden the subset of people who benefit from the exploitation of the land--spiritually, we are still in exile. we enforce scarcity upon ourselves by continuing to extract from the land without giving back our care and tenderness. 4/

we were built to be stewards of the land. to tend it, to manage it, to maintain balance for the harmony of the entire ecosystem.

colonialism sought and continues to seek to exploit land of its resources to fuel the greed of the few at the expense of the many. 3/

the necessity of farming to produce our food is portrayed by breishit as a punishment for our most ancient mistake: greed.

we abandoned the abundance of gan eden out of desire for the one thing we could not have. 2/

labor is dignified. labor sustains life. but it is not life's purpose.

fatphobia kills.

tl;dr "israel turned swamps into farmland" is NOT the dunk you think it is.

draining the hula wetlands caused the extinction of multiple endemic species. widespread erosion led to horrific underground fires. agricultural runoff polluted the kinneret.

the wetlands have been partially restored but the damage is incalculable.

the hula valley has been inhabited since the stone age. its wetlands hosted one of the most rich and diverse habitats of historic palestine. for centuries, local bedouins made a living weaving the papyrus growing there.

the JNF turned it into farmland in the 1950s.

"making the desert bloom" was one of the most eurocentric and environmentally disastrous zionist undertakings.

draining the swamps did a lot for eradicating malaria--but it also had devastating environmental consequences that led to disruptions of GLOBAL bird migrations.

may their memory bring comfort to their families and justice to the world.
/f

6/ one day, over the radio, they heard their mother's name. she had survived. years after thinking they had abandoned her to be killed, they were reunited.

the reunion with their father never came. in 1999, ze'ev submitted testimony on his father's death to yad vashem (below). https://t.co/JpxcXZXakG

5/ they stayed in the detainment camp until the establishment of the state of israel, when they made aliyah.

still children, they managed to find an uncle to help them get by in israel.

as they grew, they often listened to the radio program of survivors searching for relatives.

4/ when the war was finally over, the orphans found their way onto a ship to palestine. for a while on the boat, ze'ev thought he'd lost track of silvie--but they finally found one another.

their ship was stopped by the british. they were sent to a detainment camp in cyprus.

3/ they found partisans in the woods and lived with them until the end of the war.

one day, they left the partisans to search for their father's corpse in a mass grave. they didn't know what would be better--to find him, or not to find him.

they didn't find him.

2/ eventually their turn came to be deported.

on the train, there was a slightly open window. ze'ev and his sister silvia (two years older than him) flung themselves out of the moving train and ran into the forest.

they left their mother behind. they didn't have a choice.

1/ i never knew my wife's grandfather, ze'ev--he passed away before i met her. but i'm thinking about him a lot today.

MLK knew his assassination was coming--it was just a matter of time. but it did not stop him from using his voice for justice. his prophetic words are worth revisiting over and over.

if you haven't, watch this clip and heard his words in his own voice--
 https://t.co/1ipZrOrgXq

"Mine eyes have seen the glory of the coming of the Lord."

king's last words in public, a reference to a patriotic union-era song, again mirror moses's last words: "Who is like you, A people delivered by the LORD, Your protecting Shield, your Sword triumphant!" 6/

...he needs them to know that there is a way forward without him. the movement is far greater than any one man--it is a manifestation of g-d's will on earth.

"So I'm happy today, I'm not worried, I'm not fearing any man."

mirrors moses's final line: how happy are you, israel!5/

"And I've looked over, and I've seen the promised land.
I may not get there with you.
But I want you to know tonight that we, as a people, will get to the promised land."

king is aware of how terrifying his death will be for the movement, but... 4/

there's a subtle humility in king's reference to those who know the text. moses doesn't enter the promised land because he committed a sin of arrogance. but king doesn't focus on his own fate, except insofar as it impacts his people: 3/

"Like anybody, I would like to live a long life--longevity has its place.
But I'm not concerned about that now.
I just want to do God's will.
And he has allowed me to go up to the mountain."

this is a profound meditation on leadership. 2/
